metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: eddy covariance system of Sidaoqiao superstation, 2022
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Sidaoqiao superstation eddy covariance system (EC) in the downstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2022. The site (101.1374° E, 42.0012° N) was located in the Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region . The elevation is 873 m. The EC was installed at a height of 3.2 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.15 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of data collection techniques used to monitor energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: In the oasis–desert ecosystems, data collection techniques include the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data. Additionally, hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and gradients of air temperature and humidity are observed from automatic weather stations.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting long-term observation data in arid inland river basins?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced in arid inland river basins involves ecological environment degradation, including the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent occurrence of dust storms, which complicates long-term data collection efforts.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of data collection in arid and semiarid regions?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system in this context refers to a method used to measure and calculate vertical turbulent fluxes within the atmosphere, such as energy, water vapor, and carbon dioxide, typically employed in arid and semi-arid regions to study oasis–desert ecosystems. This method involves instruments like ultrasonic anemometers and gas analyzers to capture high-frequency data on wind speed, temperature, and gas concentrations.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'oasis–desert interactions' in understanding ecological stability?
Definition.Answer: The significance of 'oasis–desert interactions' lies in their crucial role in maintaining the ecological stability and agricultural productivity within oasis regions. Understanding these interactions helps in managing the balance of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, ultimately supporting ecological security and sustainable socioeconomic development in arid and semi-arid areas.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in data collection challenges between oases in the HRB and other inland river basins, like the Tarim River basin, in terms of environmental degradation?
Comparison.Answer: Both the HRB and the Tarim River basin face challenges such as river drying, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and dust storms. However, the specific environmental and climatic conditions leading to these challenges may differ, affecting the data collection approaches and the focus of ecological monitoring efforts in each region.

Interpretation.Question: How can the observed patterns in energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data inform sustainable development practices in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed patterns in energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data can provide insights into the interactions between oasis and desert systems, which are crucial for maintaining ecological stability and supporting the socioeconomic development of oases. This understanding is significant for achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality and ensuring the ecological security of these regions.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in data collection and processing might arise from the environmental conditions in arid and semiarid inland river basins, and how can these be mitigated?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in data collection and processing may include ecological environment degradation such as drying rivers, vegetation degradation, intensified desertification, and dust storms. These challenges can be mitigated by employing long-term observational datasets, using advanced data processing techniques like Eddypro software for quality control, and ensuring a comprehensive data collection strategy that includes hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of half-hourly turbulent flux data and hydrometeorological observations enhance the understanding of oasis-desert interactions?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of half-hourly turbulent flux data with hydrometeorological observations enhances the understanding of oasis-desert interactions by providing a comprehensive picture of energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, and other environmental parameters. This approach allows for a quantitative understanding of these exchanges, which is crucial for recognizing oasis-desert interactions and supporting ecological and socioeconomic stability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it critical to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial to achieve sustainable development goals in arid regions. Oases play a vital ecological role and support significant economic activities, particularly in western China. Understanding the interactions and energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges between these ecosystems is essential for ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of implementing Eddypro software for processing eddy covariance data in terms of data quality and usability?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing Eddypro software for processing eddy covariance data can enhance data quality and usability by applying necessary corrections such as coordinate rotation and frequency response correction. This leads to a more accurate representation of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes, which is crucial for understanding oasis-desert interactions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the exclusion of data with high missing rates or post-precipitation affect the reliability of datasets collected from oasis-desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Excluding data with high missing rates or post-precipitation ensures the reliability of datasets by minimizing errors and biases. This practice improves the quality of half-hourly flux data, leading to more dependable insights into the interactions within oasis-desert ecosystems, which are vital for ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using long-term observational datasets from oasis-desert systems on understanding the carbon balance in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using long-term observational datasets from oasis-desert systems provides critical insights into the carbon balance in arid regions. It supports the identification of these areas as carbon sinks, thereby contributing to the global carbon cycle understanding and aiding in achieving carbon neutrality goals in such ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting and processing long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, support ecological security, and promote sustainable development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain detailed observational datasets involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters in arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to maintain these datasets to quantitatively understand the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas, which is crucial for recognizing oasis-desert interactions and protecting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in processing raw eddy covariance data to ensure its quality and usability for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures involved in processing raw eddy covariance data include steps such as despiking to remove outliers, time delay correction, coordinate rotation (second rotation), frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Quality assessment is also performed, focusing on atmospheric stability and turbulent similarity characteristics. The processed data is then screened by removing erroneous data, precipitation-affected data, and data with more than 10% missing rate in the original 10Hz data within a 30-minute period.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How do researchers maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems to achieve sustainable development in arid and semiarid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems by understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems. This understanding is achieved through long-term observations and analyses, which provide quantitative insights into the interactions within oasis–desert areas. Such studies are significant for ecological stability, socioeconomic development, and achieving goals like carbon peaking and carbon neutrality.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to ensure the reliability and accuracy of hydrometeorological data collected from automatic weather stations in oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure the reliability and accuracy of hydrometeorological data collected from automatic weather stations, the data collection method involves observing parameters like radiation, soil heat flux, temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles with a 10-minute average period. These methods are supplemented by additional data such as groundwater table measurements, and the entire dataset undergoes stringent data processing and quality control procedures.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the accurate measurement of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for measuring turbulent fluxes, along with automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data with a 10-minute average period, enable accurate measurement of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collected using eddy covariance systems in oasis–desert ecosystems require extensive processing and quality control before it can be used for analysis?
Expectation.Answer: Data collected using eddy covariance systems often require extensive processing and quality control to ensure accuracy and reliability. This includes steps like removing outliers, correcting delay times, performing coordinate rotations, and making various atmospheric corrections. Additionally, data quality is assessed based on atmospheric stability and turbulence characteristics. Ensuring such processing is crucial for obtaining meaningful insights into energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise when establishing long-term observational datasets in arid regions, and how can these affect the expected outcomes of ecological research?
Expectation.Answer: Establishing long-term observational datasets in arid regions can be challenging due to environmental degradation, such as drying rivers, vegetation loss, land desertification, and dust storms. These factors can disrupt data collection and affect the consistency and reliability of datasets, which are essential for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. Such challenges may lead to data gaps and increased difficulty in drawing robust conclusions about ecological dynamics and sustainability in oasis–desert systems.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems, and what are the expected outcomes if this balance is not achieved?
Expectation.Answer: Maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial to achieve sustainable development and ecological stability in these regions. Oases are vital for supporting local populations and agriculture. If this balance is not achieved, it could lead to ecological degradation, threatening both environmental security and socio-economic development. This balance is also important for achieving goals related to carbon peaking and neutrality, as oasis–desert systems can significantly impact regional and global carbon cycles.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the potential challenges faced in maintaining data quality for long-term observations in arid and semiarid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Maintaining data quality in arid and semiarid regions can be challenging due to environmental factors like dust storms and land desertification, which may affect sensor accuracy and data integrity. The data processing steps, including quality evaluations based on atmospheric stability and turbulence characteristics, are essential to mitigate these challenges. Additionally, ensuring the robustness of instruments under harsh climatic conditions is important for reliable long-term data.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the data from an eddy covariance system can be processed to ensure high-quality flux measurements in oasis–desert ecosystems.
Assertion.Answer: The data from an eddy covariance system is processed using software like Eddypro, which involves steps such as outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, the quality of each flux measurement is evaluated based on atmospheric stationarity and turbulence similarity characteristics.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when collecting long-term observational data in arid inland river basins.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in collecting long-term observational data in arid inland river basins include ecological environment degradation issues like the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how a dataset from an oasis–desert system can contribute to understanding carbon balance in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: A dataset from an oasis–desert system can contribute to understanding carbon balance in arid regions by providing data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. This information is crucial for recognizing interactions between oasis and desert systems, which affects the carbon balance and plays a significant role in the global carbon cycle.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest a comprehensive approach to collect and process data for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, considering the challenges faced in arid and semiarid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: A comprehensive approach should include the establishment of a suite of observational datasets from both artificial and natural oasis–desert systems. This should involve long-term monitoring of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, complemented by auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. The use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for half-hourly turbulent flux data is recommended. Automatic weather stations can provide hydrometeorological data with a 10-minute average period. Data collection should be followed by robust data processing, quality control, and archiving procedures to ensure data reliability and accessibility.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose a dataset expansion strategy to enhance the understanding of hydrometeorological dynamics in the HRB, particularly focusing on the integration of vegetation and soil parameters.
Request/Directive.Answer: A dataset expansion strategy could involve the establishment of more flux and meteorological stations across diverse locations within the HRB to capture spatial variability. The inclusion of detailed vegetation and soil surveys can provide additional context for observed fluxes. Collaborations with remote sensing initiatives can enhance spatial coverage and provide continuous monitoring. Furthermore, integrating existing datasets from national and international data centers could provide a more comprehensive understanding of the region's hydrometeorological dynamics.
